summary: This is an email chain discussing the timeline of events leading up to Jeffrey Epstein's death in custody at MCC New York. The correspondence includes verification requests about the accuracy of the timeline and concerns about releasing the information publicly due to an ongoing investigation. It details Epstein's removal from suicide watch, the failure to assign him a new cellmate, and the subsequent discovery of his death.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The subject of the timeline; details his status, movements, and ultimate death while in custody at MCC New York.

events.title: Epstein placed on suicide watch
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was placed on suicide watch and received a medical evaluation.

events.title: Epstein removed from suicide watch
events.description: After daily interaction, MCC-New York Psychology Services Department determined Epstein no longer warranted suicide watch. He was returned to the Special Housing Unit (SHU) with a requirement to have a cellmate.

events.title: Cellmate released, Epstein left without cellmate
events.description: Epstein's cellmate was taken to court and released from custody, not returning to MCC. Despite being on a PSYCH Alert requiring a cellmate, no new cellmate was assigned to Epstein after his legal visit.

events.title: Discovery of Epstein's death
events.description: Staff found Epstein unresponsive in his cell at approximately 6:33 a.m. CPR was administered, and he was transported to a hospital where he was pronounced dead at 7:36 a.m.

keyFacts: Epstein was removed from suicide watch on July 29, 2019, and placed in the SHU with a requirement to have a cellmate.
On August 9, 2019, Epstein's cellmate was released from custody and not replaced, violating the PSYCH Alert requirement for Epstein to have a cellmate.
The document indicates that after midnight on August 10, not all required checks on Epstein were performed.
Jeffrey Epstein was found unresponsive in his cell on the morning of August 10, 2019, and was pronounced dead at the hospital.
The correspondence highlights concerns about releasing the timeline publicly due to an ongoing investigation, suggesting potential interference.
